Executive Summary

Description of facility and the regulated substance handled:  Ray Terminals plans to operate a bulk liquid petroleum gas (propane) storage and distribution facility at their property in Hampton, NY. The facility will be operated in compliance with the requirements of the National Fire Protection Association(NFPA)-58, Liquified Petroleum Gas Storage, United States Department of transportation(USDOT) 49 CFR 174, and all other applicable federal, state, and local laws.   The EPA Risk Management Program Guidance for Propane Storage Facilities is organized into 9 sections. Since this facility only has flammable and no toxic chemicals covered under 40 CFR 68, and because it is a program 3 Propane Storage facility.



The Ray Terminals facility is a rail access bulk terminal storage propane(LPG) for resale to retail propane outlets. The facility consists of four (4) 60,000-gallon tanks with a total capacity of 211,200 gallons at maximum fill level (88 %).  The storage tanks are filled by transfers from rail cars.  The facility will have three part-time employees that will be on site during all fuel transfers.  A site plan has been included for reference. 



Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at facility:  Ray Terminals complies with EPA's accident prevention rule and all applicable state and local codes, and regulations. The propane storage and transfer equipment was designed, installed, and is maintained in accordance with NFPA-58 and applicable state laws and rules. Protective measures include but are not limited to emergency valves on all inlet and outlet piping, breakaway fittings, at all cargo truck loading areas, emergency relief valves, impact protection measures for all loading and loading areas, and lighting and fencing for security.



Worst case release scenario: The worst-case release scenario is the rupture of a 60,000 gallon when filled to the greatest extent allowed (88%) resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. Th

e release of approximately 224,400 lbs of propane will result in the distance to the endpoint offsite being 0.5 miles.  There are approximately 16 homes, 2 farm stands, and 1 welcome center with an estimated 100 residents within the radius.



Alternative release scenario:  The alternative is a break in a 3" diameter pipe, leading to a 10-minute release and explosion.  It is estimated that approximately 46,122 lbs of propane is released. The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite 0.30 miles with approximately 8 homes with an estimated 50 residents within the radius.



Five year accident history: The Ray Terminals facility has never had an accident involving propane system that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.  Ray Terminals has worked with the Fair Haven Fire Department in Fair Haven, Vermont to assist in emergency response. Ray Terminals with offer instructional training to local fire departments for the purpose of educating fire departments about the hazards of propane.



Emergency response program: In the event of an emergency involving their propane system, Ray Terminals will notify the Fair Haven Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency.
